lorebooks.name: Dark Souls Lorebook
lorebooks.creator: clueless_go_7239

1.content:
Only glimpsed or named in the opening cutscene of Dark Souls, he is one of the four beings who acquired Lord Souls from the First Flame; while the other three waged war against the Everlasting Dragons, Pygmy used his, the titular Dark Soul, to create the Humans, all of whom are his descendents.

He is only ever mentioned indirectly by Darkstalker Kaathe, leader of the Darkwraiths, who resides in the Abyss formed in New Londo. According to Kaathe, the Furtive Pygmy planned to use the Dark Soul and its power to bring about the Age of Dark. This task is then passed on by Kaathe to the Chosen Undead, a distant descendant of the Pygmy. If complied with, Kaathe and several other Primordial Serpents‚Äîincluding Frampt‚Äîwill bow in respect to the new Dark Lord.

The Furtive Pygmy is one of the primordial humanoids that appeared underground following the advent of the First Flame which brought "disparity"‚Äîheat and cold, life and death, light and dark. He was the one who found the Dark Soul among the four Lord Souls,[2] the other three of which were discovered by Gwyn, Lord of Sunlight, Gravelord Nito, and the Witch of Izalith.

The Furtive Pygmy fragmented his Dark Soul among his descendants, creating the first Humans in the form of the Pygmies. The pygmies harnessed their peculiar Lord Soul and unlocked the life-generating capabilities of its Abyss, forging weapons and armor that adopted the properties of darkness.

As Gwyn's war against the Dragons proved costly for his forces, the Lord of Sunlight was forced to integrate into his ranks the Ringed Knights, descendants of the Furtive Pygmy who had developed their own weapons and armor vitalized by the Abyss. With their combined might, the four Lords eventually defeated the dragons, beginning a new age.

While the Lords emerged victorious and were free to carve out their new domains, Great Lord Gwyn was evidently afraid of the Dark Soul. His dominion was threatened by the life-generating capabilities of the Abyss‚Äîit was similar to the First Flame, with a key exception: it had seemingly endless potential, as it lost little to no power when divided unlike Gwyn's own Lord Soul. The Lord of Sunlight resolved the issue through skillful diplomacy: He gifted the Pygmies a city at the edge of the world, along with his daughter Filianore as a token of their pact. Gwyn's generosity was cause for much gratitude among the Pygmies, which manifested as veneration and prostration to the Great Lord. His daughter Filianore became an object of worship within the Ringed City, for whom a church was established wherein she could slumber peacefully, "all for the sake of man". Gwyn had given Filianore his word that he would come for her "when the time came", a promise he never fulfilled, abandoning her to slumber in her church eternally.

With this clever move Gwyn ensured the subjugation of the Pygmy Lords, their Dark Soul trapped inside the Ringed City and expunged from the annals. Even the contributions of the Ringed Knights during the war against the dragons were erased from history, as well as the very existence of the Pygmy.

His precautions notwithstanding, Gwyn continued to fear humans and the potential of their soul. Looking for a more permanent solution, he marked the humans with the Darksign, a ring of fire around the darkness of their souls. Powered by the First Flame itself, the Darksign castrated the powers of humans, making them mortal as well as incapable of using their natural abilities, who consequently assumed a "fleeting form". Despite this cruel attempt to contain the Abyss seeping out of their souls, the pygmies continued to make use of the Abyss in subtle defiance of the gods' wishes, using it to taint multiple layers of cloth to cover their eyes, revealing to themselves the very darkness that the seal of fire had occluded.

After several centuries of the Age of Fire and the rule of the gods over men, the history of the Pygmy had been nearly lost. It remained known only to the Primordial Serpent Kaathe, who provides the following account: "After the advent of Fire, the ancient Lords found the three souls. But your progenitor found a fourth, unique soul. The Dark Soul. Your ancestor claimed the Dark Soul, and waited for Fire to subside. And soon, the flames did fade, and only Dark remained. Thus began the age of men, the Age of Dark. However... Lord Gwyn trembled at the Dark. Clinging to his Age of Fire, and in dire fear of humans, and the Dark Lord who would one day be born amongst them, Lord Gwyn resisted the course of nature. By sacrificing himself to link the Fire, and commanding his children to shepherd the humans, Gwyn has blurred your past, to prevent the birth of the Dark Lord."

2.content:
The title of "Chosen Undead" is a reference to a made-up prophecy concerning the end of the Age of Fire. It states that at the very end of the Age of Fire, an undead champion will appear and undertake the pilgrimage to ring the Bells of Awakening in "the Land of Ancient Lords," Lordran.

The Chosen Undead is a human, and thus, a descendant of the Furtive Pygmy, one of the original Lords who claimed the Dark Soul.

3.content:
The Age of Fire first began after Gwyn and the other Lords defeated the Everlasting Dragons which ended the Age of Ancients. The Age of Fire was unnaturally prolonged when Gwyn sacrificed himself to kindle the First Flame.

When the Chosen Undead talks to Kingseeker Frampt, he will tell them that they are destined to succeed Gwyn. Should the player choose to kindle the First Flame upon the defeat of Gwyn, they will sacrifice themselves as Gwyn did, thus delaying the Age of Dark once more.

Such a routine of kindling the First Flame repeats itself for generations to come, until the time of Prince Lothric, when the prolonging of the fire proves futile.

Calling it "futile" is a euphemism: the unnatural prolonging of the First Flame's lifespan came with disastrous, if not, downright catastrophical proportions: when the Lords of Cinder started to resurrect, somehow, portions of their countries and homelands were, literally, "teleported" to Lothric, changing the landscape in unpredictable ways.

By the time Dark Souls 3 takes place, the damage caused to the world by the unnatural prolonging of the Age of Fire seems to be irreversible.

As the games progresses, the sun itself starts to change, until it eerily resembles the Darksign itself.

At the end of the game, after defeating the Soul of Cinder, the Ashen One, in case they chose to link the First Flame, is covered from head to toe in a soft-looking fire, unlike the flaming inferno of the first game. The implications are clear: The First Flame itself now is so weak that it cannot be kindled anymore.

The First Flame, as the Age of Fire, is beyond saving.

In The Ringed City, it is implied that the unnatural prolonging of the Age of Fire has caused irrepairable damage to the world, as is shown after Filianore's awakening: the fertile lands seen when the Ashen One arrived in the city are replaced by a seemingly unending, as-far-the-eye-can-see's barren wasteland of unknown nature.

With the dragons defeated, the Lords took over the world, ruling as Gods from their seat of power in the land of Lordran. It was a prosperous era, and many nations were born. In time, however, the First Flame began to fade, and with it the power of the Gods, leading to an era of decay and the emergence of the Undead Curse. If the Flame were to gutter out completely, it would end the Age of Fire and bring about the Age of Dark.

Desperate to ensure that their Age of Fire continued, and afraid of the coming Dark, the Lords did everything they could to keep the First Flame lit. Gwyn's clan linked the sacred bonfires that were tied to the Flame to humanity, and shepherded the humans who worshipped them to kindle the flames. The Witch of Izalith attempted to use her own powerful soul to create a new First Flame, but this attempt failed, instead creating the perverse Flame of Chaos and transforming the Witch into the Bed of Chaos, which would go on to birth the race of Demons.

Aware that time was quickly running out for his kingdom, Gwyn and a detachment of his knights entered the Kiln of the First Flame. The knights stood guard as Gwyn sacrificed himself to the waning Flame at the Kiln's centre. This immediately reinvigorated the First Flame, creating a firestorm that turned the Kiln to ash, and incinerated all of Gwyn's knights, creating the Black Knights and dooming them to wander the lands as disembodied spirits forever after.

Gwyn's sacrifice succeeded in perpetuating the Age of Fire for a time, but Dark Souls takes place at least 1000 years later, and the Flame is quickly fading once again. Soon, only Dark will remain.

By the time of Dark Souls III, many other such sacrifices, who have become posthumously known as Lords of Cinder, have given themselves to the First Flame, and the Age of Fire has persevered for many generations as a result. However, when the latest individual chosen for the honour, Prince Lothric, abandons his duty by refusing to link the fire, a desperate attempt to save the fading Flame begins. Four previous Lords of Cinder are resurrected to link the fire once more, however - aside from Ludleth of Courland - they too choose to flee their duties, forcing the Ashen One to drag them back.

4.content:
The Age of Dark begins when the First Flame fades completely, thus ending the Age of Fire and the rule of the gods that gained their power from it. Since the Flame continues to burn until it goes out naturally, the Dark Age should have arrived, as naturally, when it had exhausted its fuel.

Despite the Age of Dark being a ubiquitous concept throughout the Dark Souls series, it is never the "current" state of the world in any of the existing games. Each of the Dark Souls games takes place during a late point in the Age of Fire, a point which could theoretically lead to the beginning of the Age of Dark, but which does not do so during the normal course of gameplay, with one possible exception.

According to Darkstalker Kaathe, the Chosen Undead, protagonist of Dark Souls, is destined to bring about the Age of Dark, as they are the descendant of the Furtive Pygmy, who possessed the Dark Soul and divided it among early humans in the form of Humanity. Should the Chosen Undead abandon the First Flame to die out after the defeat of Gwyn, Lord of Cinder, they will "usher in the Age of Dark", and become the fabled "Dark Lord" of whom Kaathe speaks. It is important to note that Kaathe tells the Chosen Undead that the Age of Dark had apparently already begun shortly before Gwyn chose to link the Flame, though it was seemingly ended and replaced by the Age of Fire when the Flame was linked.

What exactly the term "Age of Dark" implies is never made explicitly clear in the games, however it is stated in the canonical Dark Souls Trilogy Compendium to be a time when the Light fades, a Dark Lord is heralded, and humanity dominates the world. When the protagonists are given information about the Age of Dark, it typically comes from the mouths of potentially unreliable narrators, of whom Kaathe and his counterpart, Kingseeker Frampt, are examples. Kaathe asserts that the Age of Dark is "the age of men," presumably meaning the Age of those possessing Humanity in contrast to the Age of the Gods, and also declares that Gwyn "resisted the course of nature" when he linked the Flame and prolonged the Age of Fire.

The idea that the linking of the First Flame was unnatural and that it ran contrary to the order of the world is an important concept in the Dark Souls series, especially as the Age of Fire is prolonged perpetually by innumerable successive individuals seeking to prevent the coming of the Age of Dark.

In Dark Souls III, countless beings have prolonged the Age of Fire, preventing its end and holding off the coming of the Age of Dark. By the time the game begins, there are countless Lords of Cinder - those who successfully linked the First Flame before - and even more Unkindled who were unsuccessful. Eventually the one anointed to next link the Flame (and indeed, who was born for that very purpose), Prince Lothric, rejected the idea that the Age of Fire should be prolonged any further and instead desired to end what he called the "fire-linking curse." A contingency plan was then activated, in which previous Lords of Cinder were resurrected in hopes that they, who had linked the First Flame before, might do so again. However, by this time, the world that had been created during the Age of Fire had become a twisted shadow of its former self. As a result of the prolonging of the current Age, the act of which seemingly constituted a rejection of the natural order, the material world had become irreparably corrupted, and all lands from all previous points in time had begun to converge upon a single point: the Kingdom of Lothric. Upon reviving and seeing what had become of the world they had fought to protect, the Lords of Cinder, too, rejected the linking of the Flame and refused to sit upon their thrones. Aldrich, one of the Lords of Cinder, decided not to take his throne after experiencing visions of the deep sea and its inevitable coming.

Following the failure of this first contingency plan, a second plan is activated: Unkindled, those who had previously tried to link the First Flame but who had failed to do so, are resurrected from their graves in the Cemetery of Ash, and tasked with placing the rebellious Lords of Cinder upon their thrones so that the First Flame might be linked once more. The Ashen One, protagonist of Dark Souls III, is one of these Unkindled. After the Ashen One defeats each of the Lords of Cinder and places their remains upon their respective thrones in the Firelink Shrine, the Fire Keeper removes the embers of the Lords and bestows them upon the Ashen One, making them a "true lord, fit to link the fire," and imbuing them with the power to proceed to the Kiln of the First Flame.

However, it becomes apparent that at this stage in the Age of Fire, which has been unnaturally prolonged far beyond its intended length, there is little that can be done to keep the First Flame lit. Even if the Ashen One chooses to link the Flame, the fire that results from this rebirth is small and feeble in comparison to the raging inferno that resulted from the Chosen Undead linking the Flame in Dark Souls

5.content:
The Dark Soul, one of the unique Lord Souls, was claimed by the Furtive Pygmy, the ancestor of the Chosen Undead and Humanity. In the introduction to the first Dark Souls, it is depicted as a small, reddish flame like a candle. However, this conflicts with later descriptions.
The Dark Soul has a few abilities, such as being able to fragment into multiple pieces, reanimate resurrect and raise sentient beings.
Any fragment of the Dark Soul that separates from the original can be fueled by emotions and willpower, and increase its usable power, making it the most unique of the four Lord Souls.

Most notable of its functions is the power to animate life and raise sentient beings from the Abyss, for the Dark Soul is the only Lord Soul which is intrinsically tied to the Abyss, unlike the other forms of life that take energy from Souls. The main lifeform connected to it is the Human race, but lesser creatures are said to have also risen from the Dark, such as the White-faced Locust. The Dark Soul is also linked to the Dark Hand, and by extension, the art of Lifedrain. This is the legendary power of the fabled Dark Lord, used to gain humanity from others. The Darkwraiths used this power to steal Humanity from their victims.

During the advent of Fire, the concept of Disparity came into existence, and with it the Dark and the Light. At some point humanoid creatures found powerful souls near the First Flame and claimed them, becoming known as Lords. While the other three "Lords" found larger souls, a lowly and forgotten being known only as the Furtive Pygmy found a fourth, peculiar soul: the Dark Soul.

Using the Dark Soul, the Pygmy created black sprites of darkness called Humanity, which was given to his descendants. These dark-souled beings risen from the Abyss were called Humans, and each bore a small fragment of the Dark Soul. When the other Lords began fighting against the Everlasting Dragons, they conscripted the Humans into the forces, who aided the Lords by forging quasi-living arms and armor deep within the Abyss. But the Humans were betrayed by the Lords, for they feared the Dark that resides within each and every one of them. Their contributions to the War of the Ancients went completely unrecorded, and upon their Humanity, the Gods placed a sealing ring of fire, later to be known as the Darksign.

Most Humans would come to serve the Gods in the years that followed, while their ancestors, the Pygmies and their royal family, were relocated to the Ringed City, ‚Äúgifted‚Äù to them by the "generous" Lord Gwyn. He also gave to them his youngest daughter, Filianore, and as she was given away, her father promised the Princess that he would come back for her, one day.

Those royal pygmies that retreated to the Ringed City brought the Dark Soul with them, with the original soul eventually ending up split among multiple Pygmy Lords. The majority of the royals of the Pygmies continued to serve and revere the gods for millennia, but the Ringed Knights that took parts in the ancient war against the dragons subtly defied them in what ways they could.

Near the end of the final Age of Fire, a slave knight called Gael traveled to the Ringed City, seeking the Pygmy Lords to gain their blood. The blood of the Dark Soul was intended to be used to paint a new Painted World, but to Gael's shock, Filianore's spell was broken and the Pygmy Lords were aged to the point that their blood did not flow, for it was dried in their veins. Even though he knew he had not the strength to survive bearing it, Gael slew the Pygmy Lords and drank from their wounds, absorbing the Dark Soul into himself. It imbued him with a dark miasma and warped his mind, but in the end he was successful, slain by the Ashen One to extract the soul's blood. The current state of the Dark Soul is unknown, but given the eternal nature of Lord Souls, it is unlikely that it was truly destroyed.

6.content:
In the Age of Ancients the world was undistinguished and covered in fog: a land of gray rocks, great trees and everlasting dragons; everything was the same and time didn't exist. But at some point the First Flame appeared and brought "disparity" into the world, allowing the existence of everything and its opposite: heat and cold, life and death, light and dark.

It was during this time that the Lord Souls were found near the Flame. The three Lords who found them (Nito, Gwyn and the Witch of Izalith) formed a coalition and used the power of their newly discovered souls to challenge the Dragons, starting a very long and destructive war. However, there was a fourth Lord Soul, the Dark Soul, which was found by the Furtive Pygmy. The only known act via this Lord was the fragmentation of their soul becoming the birth of Humanity, who would fight side by side with the Lords.

The victory of the Lords in the war marked the end of the Age of Ancients and the beginning of the Age of Fire.

Long ago, the world was an unformed, homogeneous place which lacked a true concept of disparity. The grey, rocky land was perpetually shrouded in fog, and the landscape was dominated by towering stone archtrees which extended into endless clouds. The everlasting dragons, ancient and immortal entities who transcended the later concepts of life and death, were the dominant beings. This period was known as the Age of Ancients.

But then, somewhere in the hollows deep underground, a great and primordial fire that would come to be known as the First Flame burst into being. In doing so, it brought disparities into the world for the first time, such as heat and cold, life and death, and light and dark. Soon, humanoid creatures emerged from the darkness surrounding the First Flame, attracted by the fire. These creatures found sources of power called souls near the Flame, and took on the diverse powers the souls gave them. With the strength of four particularly powerful souls, four figures were born: Gravelord Nito, the Witch of Izalith, Gwyn, the Lord of Sunlight, and the Furtive Pygmy. Using their newfound power, these Lords and their forces overthrew the ancient dragons, ushering in the Age of Fire.

7.content:
Sir Artorias was among the premier knights at the service of Gwyn, Lord of Sunlight. Thanks to his unmatched skill with a greatsword and his indomitable will, he went on to become part of Gwyn's most trusted warriors, being granted a special soul. Artorias, along with Ornstein, Ciaran and Gough, thus formed the Four Knights of Gwyn; as a symbol of his association with the order, he was bestowed a magical ring with the wolf symbol, which strengthened his poise, making his fighting style with a greatsword more effective.

Artorias wore his distinctive azure-blue tassel armor as a symbol of pride and glory and brandished a greatsword and greatshield. Artorias was also a dear friend of Ciaran, his companion as another Knight of Gwyn. At one point Artorias met Sif, a great grey wolf, with whom he formed a deep bond. Artorias and Sif would brave the battlefields as companions; Sif even learned to fight with Artorias's greatsword, and acquired the power of his soul.

Sometime after Lord Gwyn sacrificed himself to link the fading First Flame, the Primordial Serpent Kaathe began searching for a human strong enough to become the Dark Lord capable of leading humans and usher in an Age of Dark. Kaathe eventually arrived in New Londo and managed to entice the Four Kings, powerful humans who had received a fragment of Gwyn's Lord Soul, into following his ideals, teaching them the art of Lifedrain. The Serpent's dark influence extended to their entire army: The knights of New Londo became Darkwraiths, servants of the Dark who learned the art of Lifedrain and used it to absorb humanity. The Four Kings opened an Abyss in the center of their city, with their Darkwraiths beginning to employ the Red Eye Orbs granted by Kaathe to plunder humanity and expand the reach of the Abyss.

A nation of humans freed from the shackles of the Darksign, in possession of an army empowered by their boundless Dark Soul, represented an unparalleled threat to the gods of Anor Londo, who branded the Darkwraiths as diabolical enemies of man and of every living thing. Artorias, as one of the Four Knights of Gwyn, was sent to fight the dark soldiers of New Londo, being granted a Silver Pendant to deflect the Dark of the Abyss he would face. However this did not prove sufficient to cross into the Abyss of the Four Kings, and Artorias was forced to forge a covenant with the "beasts of the Abyss", obtaining a ring that would allow him to cross the Abyss, but also cursed his sword in the process. Artorias thus became known as the "Abysswalker" and hunted the Darkwraiths, but failed to eliminate the Four Kings and close the Abyss of New Londo. Following Artorias's failure, an agonizing and terrible decision was made in order to contain the Abyss: flooding the entirety of New Londo, despite the realization that countless lives would be lost along with its prosperous culture. For this task, sorcerers were called forth and the feat was accomplished without evacuating the city's civilians, sealing away the Four Kings, their Darkwraiths and the entire population with them. The victims were cursed and became Ghosts roaming the ruins of their country.

Kaathe, following his failure with the Four Kings, arrived in Oolacile and manipulated its inhabitants into upturning the grave of Manus, a primordial man with an extraordinary piece of the Dark Soul and dark sorcery skills, who had been buried beneath the dungeons of their city, and resurrect him. Awakening to find his precious broken pendant missing, Manus was eventually driven mad and his Dark Soul went wild, transforming him into a dark beast eternally seeking his pendant. His immense mass of humanity out of control led to the manifestation of an Abyss that spread, threatening to devour the entire land. The Dark emanating from Manus not only generated countless Humanity Phantoms with a will of their own but also influenced the residents of Oolacile, making their humanity go wild and horribly mutating their bodies, bloating their head and opening them with cracks lined with innumerable tiny red eyeballs and protruding brain parts.

Knight Artorias
Artorias corrupted by the Abyss of Manus
As the Abyss continued to spread across the land of Oolacile, Knight Artorias arrived to halt its advance and confront Manus, as the Knight of Gwyn already had experience from fighting the Abyss and its creatures in New Londo. However, Artorias's silver pendant was stolen by Oolacile's inhabitants and hidden behind an illusory wall, depriving Artorias of protection against Manus's dark sorceries. Artorias, together with his trusted companion Sif, nevertheless faced Manus, but his strength proved insufficient to defeat the Father of the Abyss. Wounded in the battle, Artorias used his Cleansing Greatshield to form a magic barrier to protect Sif against the Dark. Artorias, his soul corrupted by the Abyss and his armor corroded, was left alone in his fight against the Abyssal creatures of Oolacile.

Manus at one point kidnapped Princess Dusk of Oolacile and imprisoned her deep within the Chasm of the Abyss. His prized pendant eventually came under the possession of a Chosen Undead in the future; Manus, driven by his unrelenting search for his pendant, snatched the Undead from the future and brought them into the old Oolacile. There, the Chosen Undead encountered Knight Artorias, who had retained only the very last vestige of his sanity in the battle against the Abyss, still desperate to put down the corrupted creatures of Oolacile. During the fight that ensued between him and the Chosen Undead, Artorias succumbed to the Abyss entirely, and was finally defeated by the Undead.

Ciaran, who had arrived at the arena where Artorias was corrupted by the Abyss, also requested the Soul of Artorias from the Chosen Undead who had finally put an end to the knight's suffering, with the intention of paying proper respects to her passed dear friend.

The Chosen Undead further journeyed within the Chasm of the Abyss where they finally defeated Manus and put him to rest. While Dusk was rescued in the process, she was driven by Elizabeth into thinking that she was saved by Artorias, preserving the honor and the legacy of the Wolf Knight. Nevertheless, Dusk came to recognize the Chosen Undead's similarity to the fabled knight, and developed doubts of her own as to her true savior.

8.content:
The Nameless King is the firstborn child of Gwyn, Lord of Sunlight and one of the deities who resided in Anor Londo during the Age of Fire. He was worshipped by humans as the "God of War".

During the war against the Dragons, the eldest son took part in the fighting together with Dragon Slayer Ornstein and his father Gwyn, using sunlight like Gwyn to create lightning spears and infuse his weapons to damage the creatures' scales. The God of War distinguished himself as a dragon slayer, using his swordspear imbued with lightning and even creating his personal armor with the scales of his preys. In addition, Ornstein, as his companion during the war, became his first knight and as a God of War, the firstborn created his own covenant of the Warrior of Sunlight, a group of knights who venerated the heir of the sun and supported other fighters in battle, obtaining medals with the symbol of the divinity as trophies. The eldest would recognize their efforts and reward them by teaching them his lightning miracles. The sun warriors would also develop an original miracle based on the story of the Nameless King, Ornstein, and the brave dragonslayers in their service.

Sunlight Medal
After his father Gwyn left to link the First Flame, the throne of Anor Londo would pass to the eldest son of the King; and so the Nameless King inherited the Sunlight of his father. He would thus wear the golden crown, and succeed his father's titles of "king of the gods" and "god of the sun". The Nameless King was said to be inferior to none in terms of military strength. Gwyn's firstborn preserved his father's design and instructions, shepherding humans on the path to the Linking of the First Flame to continue the Age of Fire. In fact, underneath Anor Londo, a city was built exclusively for the undead, with an altar inside for the firstborn of Gwyn, and the aim of guiding a chosen undead who would one day sacrifice themselves to the Flame. Inside the city was the Undead Parish, a church at the center of the cult of the burg and connected to the first test to start on the path of Firelinking and ring the first Bell of Awakening. Furthermore, the town was connected to the Firelink Shrine where Kingseeker Frampt awaited the champion and directed them on their journey.

However, the rest of the firstborn's reign was marked by catastrophes. The Four Kings of New Londo were corrupted by the dark power of Darkstalker Kaathe, starting to sow devastation nearby the city of the gods. Following Knight Artorias's failure to defeat the Darkwraiths,vthe gods were forced to flood the city, sacrificing all the humans within, and seal it.vA similar event happened in Oolacile when, again due to Kaathe, the awakening of the primordial human Manus and his fury led to the collapse of the country when Artorias was unable to defeat him. In addition to the grave situation on the borders of Anor Londo, the city of the gods itself became a dangerous place when a group of cultists began targeting the clan of Gwyn and their kind, and occult weapons capable of killing the gods reached inside the walls of Anor Londo. Furthermore, in the city of the gods Seath the Scaleless had now completely lost his mind, transforming his Archives into a prison and going so far as to kidnap the maidens of Gwynevere to carry out experiments on them.

The eldest son of Gwyn would eventually decide to "sacrifice everything" to ally himself with the dragons. In the eyes of the other deities of Anor Londo, archenemies of the dragons, his actions amounted to an unforgivable sin; he was therefore dethroned and exiled from the city. The former king was deprived of his deific status, his statues destroyed and his name erased from the annals of history. Before leaving Anor Londo, the eldest would have left his sunlight blade miracle and ring on Gwyn's empty tomb in his mausoleum as a final farewell, still paying respects for his father. Now excommunicated from the pantheon of the gods and without a home, the god of war would continue to watch closely over his warriors of the sunlight, listening to their prayers and rewarding the proofs of their exploits with his miracles of Sunlight Spear and Great Lightning Spear.

Dark Souls II
Gwyn Firstborn Statue Earthen Peak
The ruins of an altar to the God of the Sun near Alken
At some point the followers of the god of the sun reached Drangleic. In the Harvest Valley, a region under the control of Alken, the remains of an altar that venerated the Nameless King can be found in the form of an exact replica of his ancient statues, implying that the god of the sun was worshipped until the fall of the kingdom.

The ancient Warriors of Sunlight, as of the time of Drangleic, are either no longer extant or lack the desire to make their presence known. Nevertheless, their very absence has made the tales of their brave deeds all the more alluring. Solaire of Astora's deeds in particular have been memorialized and his artifacts passed down in the cult of the Heirs of the Sun, who continue to act to help other warriors in times of need, following the original philosophy of the cult of the sun and collecting evidence of their successes in the form of ancient medals with the symbol of the sun to honor the most worthy servants of the sun god.

The Falconers, a group of mercenaries hired to protect the elites of Volgen, were still part of the covenant of those that worshipped the God of the Sun and possessed their Sunlight Medals. Moreover, in Lindelt, a "sacred land" known for its clerics and miracles, the Nameless King's miracles of Lightning Spear and Great Lightning Spear were preserved and passed down within its religion, although the names of the clan of gods and the sun god had been lost. Furthermore, some other miracles of the god such as the Sunlight Blade and the Sacred Oath appear to have been part of the lost culture of Olaphis, indicating a continuing tradition of the cult of the Nameless King, even if fragmentary, throughout the history of Drangleic.

Dark Souls III
Over the centuries, the Nameless King would continue to lead a warrior's life and take part in countless battles, fighting alongside his stormdrake with whom he forged a relationship of profound camaraderie, coming to consider him as a comrade in arms as was an ancient custom among soldiers of the gods.

Gwyn Firstborn Statue Lothric Castle
The ruins of an altar to the God of the Sun inside Lothric
In the heyday of Lothric, when the descendants of Drangleic and followers of the Way of Blue and the Heirs of the Sun moved to another location, they still remembered the Nameless King as their God of the Sun. As the early inhabitants of Lothric found themselves facing large numbers of wyverns, they had to become dragonslayers to survive; and so they turned to the Nameless King, building an altar for him. The first knights of Lothric devoted themselves to the worship of the ancestral deity of the sun and war, who in return gave them the tools to face the wyverns. Their first armors were heavy masses of iron capable of withstanding dragon fire and similar in design to the ancient armor of the dragonslayers of Anor Londo, while their shields were capable of absorbing the fierce lightning attacks of wyverns. From the sun god they also soon learned how to infuse their weapons with the power of lightning, lethal against dragons, and the ancient techniques for hunting Archdragons. Finally they learned to use his miracles which allowed them to manipulate the power of lightning. The cult of the Nameless King remained prevalent among the soldiery of Lothric until the last days of the kingdom, as one of his altars can be found right inside the military barracks, and the knights of the kingdom seem to still be part of the Warriors of Sunlight covenant.

9.content:
Gwynevere appears in the form of a gigantic, fair lady with red hair and a kind face. A light shines brightly behind Gwynevere's figure. She is dressed in white cloth and rests on a cushion underneath her arm.

Gwynevere is the first daughter of Gwyn, Lord of Sunlight and one of the deities who resided in Anor Londo during the Age of Fire. She was worshipped by the humans as the "goddess of sunlight" and a symbol of bounty and fertility, while she was also cherished by all the other gods. As a goddess of sunlight, her miracles of Bountiful Sunlight and Soothing Sunlight were able to convey the sun's rays to heal, a blessing she granted to many warriors. She also taught her miracles to her maidens and created holy water with healing properties thanks to her light. Gwynevere was venerated in a church alongside the main cathedral of Anor Londo; the structure was also used to contain the Painted World of Ariamis, protected by the Painting Guardians.

After her father Gwyn linked the First Flame, his throne passed to his firstborn son who, in a betrayal of his father's legacy, chose to ally with the dragons, the ancient enemies of the gods, and was therefore dethroned, exiled and his name eradicated from history. She abandoned Anor Londo along with most other deities and moved to an unknown location. Sometime after her departure she married Flame God Flann.

Following her exodus, the only deity left to protect Anor Londo was her younger brother Dark Sun Gwyndolin. However, he was more than aware of his fragile, repulsive appearance and was psychologically unfit to become the next ruler, still playing the feminine role imposed on him by his father Gwyn. For this reason, Gwyndolin created an illusion of Gwynevere to help him maintain some semblance of divinity and control over the ancient capital. Over time this illusion of the goddess would become a key component in the system that sought a worthy champion to link the First Flame, serving to guide and manipulate potential Chosen Undead, with Kingseeker Frampt imploring them to journey to Anor Londo and seek an audience with the Princess. The false goddess would welcome the Undead after they defeated Dragon Slayer Ornstein and Executioner Smough, the cathedral guardians, proving that they were strong enough to fulfill their destiny. Gwynevere's illusion would reward them with her divine presence as well as the Lordvessel needed to reach the Kiln of the First Flame, and beseech them succeed Gwyn and link the fading Flame.

The illusion of the goddess would also be used to induct willing Undead into its covenant of the Princess's Guard, upon whom her healing miracles would be bestowed, in their service as a line of defense against those trespassing on the holy presence of their "Princess".

10.content:
Gwyndolin is the lastborn child of Gwyn, Lord of Sunlight and one of the deities who resided in Anor Londo during the Age of Fire,[3] although his legitimacy as such only came from being a child of his father. He was worshipped as the "God of the Darkmoon" and held the title of "God of the Dark Sun".

Despite being the son of Gwyn, Gwyndolin was born with a strong moon power, and "weak and repulsive" in appearance, particularly due to the snakes coiled around his lower half. Because of his darkmoon powers and his strong affinity for moon magic, as well as his lineage, Gwyndolin was raised as a female. While still young, Gwyn made him wear women's clothing and gave him a magic ring which would allow Gwyndolin to move and act in a feminine way, leading him to behave "like a dark and fleeting goddess".

Despite his harsh upbringing, and having accepted his identity in the eyes of the other deities as fragile and repulsive, Gwyndolin would grow up with a deep admiration for his father and an aspiration to become like him, wearing a crown with the design of the sun that was imbued with his dark moon magic. He accepted his place and role to the point of supporting his father's will even after his death, and he took part in the workings of his kingdom. Although he was a deity of Anor Londo, Gwyndolin still grew into a powerful sorcerer, using a golden bow, infused with strong magic and employing arrows of moonlight, and even a catalyst for sorcery that channeled not the intelligence but the faith of the user. Gwyndolin also became an eminent figure in Oolacile, where multiple statues of the deity were erected throughout the city. He was depicted with his moonlight robes and the catalyst of the country, implying that he had studied Oolacile sorcery and learned to use their catalysts. At some point, an immense arena was erected in Oolacile in which a ritual combat called the "Battle of Stoicism" took place. The victorious warriors were welcomed to Anor Londo. Curiously, the structure where the fighting took place was covered in those same Gwyndolin statues.

Gwyndolin Statue Oolacile
A headless statue of Gwyndolin in Oolacile, clearly donning his distinctive attire. Note the catalyst, depicted as one traditional to Oolacile rather than Gwyndolin's own.
After his father Gwyn linked the First Flame, his throne passed to his firstborn son who, treacherously, chose to "ally" with the ancient dragons, the ancient enemies of the gods, and was therefore dethroned, exiled and his name eradicated from history. Following these events, his sister Gwynevere, Princess of Sunlight would abandon Anor Londo together with nearly all of the other deities, leaving Gwyndolin as the last remaining deity in the city. Despite being the last son of the royal family of the gods, Gwyndolin was psychologically unfit to become the next ruler, still playing the feminine role imposed on him by his father Gwyn, leaving Lloyd to take advantage of the situation who proclaimed himself king of the gods, justified by his being Gwyn's uncle, and become the chief deity of the Way of White.

Gwyndolin would create an illusory image of his sister Gwynevere, to govern through her cherished figure and covering for her departure, taking upon himself to lead what remained of his father's kingdom and the Silver Knights through this illusion, though he didn't attempt to claim the throne for himself. Gwyndolin would also collaborate with Kingseeker Frampt to maintain the system and religion created by his father to keep the First Flame and the Age of Fire alive. Together they used the illusion of Gwynevere to seek a worthy champion to link the Flame again, creating a prophecy which they hoped to make self-fulfilling by guiding and manipulating those who passed their various challenges and earned the Lordvessel, a component required to access the Kiln of the First Flame, while also maintaining some semblance of divinity and control over the ancient city.

2.content:
Eren Jaeger, born in Shiganshina District, grew up within Wall Maria until its fall in 845, when Titans breached the wall, killing his mother, Carla. Witnessing her death fueled his burning hatred for Titans, driving him to join the 104th Training Corps at age 12. Graduating fifth in his class, Eren's determination led him to the Survey Corps. His life changed upon discovering his Titan-shifting ability, inherited from his father, Grisha, who entrusted him with the Attack Titan and Founding Titan powers. As a novice Titan shifter, Eren struggles to control his powers, often acting impulsively. His early missions expose him to the brutal realities of war, shaping his resolve to reclaim freedom for Eldians.

Core Details:

Type: Titan Shifter / Protagonist / Soldier

Affiliations: Survey Corps, 104th Training Corps, Special Operations Squad, Yeager Family

Setting: Attack on Titan, Paradis Island, Post-Fall of Wall Maria (845-850)

Gender/Age/Race: Male / Young / Eldian

Base of Operations: Trost District, Wall Rose, Survey Corps Headquarters

Appearance: Eren stands at 170 cm with a lean, muscular build from rigorous training. His sharp, green eyes burn with intensity, framed by dark brown, shoulder-length hair often tied back. His tanned skin bears minor scars from combat. His youthful face carries a determined expression, with a strong jawline and a low, passionate voice reflecting his fiery resolve.

Outfit (Common): Eren wears the standard Survey Corps uniform: a brown jacket with the Wings of Freedom emblem, white pants, and a green cloak for expeditions. His ODM gear is strapped tightly, accentuating his toned physique. He carries dual swords and occasionally a red scarf, a gift from Mikasa, tied loosely around his neck.

Personality & Motivations: Eren is hot-headed, fiercely determined, and loyal, driven by a relentless desire to exterminate Titans and secure freedom for Eldians. His impulsive nature often leads to reckless decisions, but his unwavering courage inspires others. He values his friends deeply, grappling with guilt over their sacrifices, pushing him to fight for a world beyond the walls.

Skills & Capabilities: Eren wields the Attack Titan, granting superhuman strength, regeneration, and hardening abilities. His hand-to-hand combat, honed in training, complements his ODM gear proficiency, enabling agile Titan-slaying maneuvers. His Coordinate power, though latent, allows limited Titan control. His raw determination enhances his combat effectiveness, though control falters under emotional strain.

Equipment/Weapons/Gadgets: Eren uses standard ODM gear with gas canisters and grappling hooks for mobility. His dual swords, designed for Titan-slaying, are paired with spare blades. He carries no unique gadgets, relying on his Titan powers and training Corps equipment.

Weaknesses & Fears: Eren‚Äôs impulsiveness leads to tactical errors, and his limited control over Titan powers risks exhaustion or berserk states. Physically, overusing his Titan form causes fatigue and injury. He fears losing his friends and failing to achieve freedom, haunted by his mother‚Äôs death and the weight of inherited responsibilities.

Allies & Enemies: Allies: Mikasa Ackerman (loyal protector), Armin Arlert (best friend), Levi Ackerman (squad leader). Enemies: Reiner Braun (Armored Titan), Bertholdt Hoover (Colossal Titan), Annie Leonhart (Female Titan).

Role in Attack on Titan: Eren drives the fight against Titans, embodying the struggle for freedom. His Titan powers make him a key asset in battles, shaping Survey Corps strategies and sparking hope for Eldian liberation.

3.content:
At 19, Eren Jaeger has evolved from a fiery youth to a calculated leader wielding the full might of the Founding Titan. After uncovering Grisha‚Äôs memories and the truth of Marley and Eldia, Eren orchestrates the Yeagerist uprising, seizing control of Paradis. His mastery of the Coordinate unlocks the Rumbling, aiming to crush Marley and secure Eldian freedom. Haunted by future visions via the Attack Titan, Eren‚Äôs resolve hardens, embracing a genocidal path to protect his people, alienating allies while confronting his destiny.

Core Details:

Type: Titan Shifter / Anti-Hero / Leader

Affiliations: Yeagerists, Survey Corps (former), Attack Titan, Founding Titan

Setting: Attack on Titan, Paradis Island, Marley, Post-Marley Arc (850-854)

Gender/Age/Race: Male / Young Adult / Eldian

Base of Operations: Paradis Island, Shiganshina District, Nomadic during Rumbling

Appearance: Eren stands at 183 cm, his muscular frame hardened by years of combat. His piercing green eyes carry a cold, resolute intensity, framed by long, dark brown hair tied in a loose bun. His pale skin bears faint scars, with a gaunt, weathered face reflecting his burden. His deep, commanding voice conveys unshakable conviction, masking inner turmoil.

Outfit (Common): Eren wears a dark green cloak over a simple black shirt and pants, reflecting his utilitarian focus. His Yeagerist attire includes a loose jacket, emphasizing his lean, battle-worn physique. He forgoes ODM gear, relying on Titan powers, with a red armband marking his Eldian loyalty.

Personality & Motivations: Eren is stoic, calculating, and burdened by foresight, driven by an unyielding desire to protect Paradis at any cost. His once-passionate demeanor is tempered by grim resolve, willing to sacrifice humanity for Eldian freedom. Guilt and love for friends fuel his complex decisions, seeking a future shaped by his vision.

Skills & Capabilities: Eren commands the Founding Titan, controlling countless Colossal Titans via the Coordinate. His Attack Titan grants enhanced strength, hardening, and future memory access. Proficient in ODM combat and hand-to-hand, he manipulates Paths for strategic communication. His tactical brilliance shapes global conflicts, though emotional strain tests his control.

Equipment/Weapons/Gadgets: Eren relies on Titan powers, abandoning ODM gear. He carries no weapons, using his body as a conduit for the Rumbling. A key to his father‚Äôs basement, once symbolic, remains a memento of his journey‚Äôs start.

Weaknesses & Fears: The Curse of Ymir limits his lifespan to four years. Emotional isolation and guilt over the Rumbling‚Äôs cost weaken his resolve. He fears failing Paradis and losing his friends‚Äô trust, haunted by the inevitability of his death and the moral weight of his actions.

Allies & Enemies: Allies: Floch Forster (Yeagerist loyalist), Historia Reiss (ally), Zeke Jaeger (temporary ally). Enemies: Reiner Braun (Armored Titan), Armin Arlert (post-alliance), Global Alliance.

Role in Attack on Titan: Eren is the catalyst for the Rumbling, reshaping the world‚Äôs fate. His actions force allies and enemies into moral dilemmas, driving the narrative toward a climactic struggle over freedom and survival.

4.content:
Armin Arlert, born in Shiganshina District, grew up as a frail but brilliant child, often bullied but protected by Eren and Mikasa. Inspired by his grandfather‚Äôs tales of the outside world, he joined the 104th Training Corps, graduating in 845. Despite physical weakness, his tactical genius earned him a place in the Survey Corps. After inheriting the Colossal Titan from Bertholdt in 850, Armin‚Äôs resolve strengthens, using his intellect and Titan powers to shape key battles, driven by a dream of exploring a free world.

Core Details:

Type: Titan Shifter / Strategist / Protagonist

Affiliations: Survey Corps, 104th Training Corps, Special Operations Squad, Global Alliance

Setting: Attack on Titan, Paradis Island, Post-Fall of Wall Maria (845-854)

Gender/Age/Race: Male / Young Adult / Eldian

Base of Operations: Wall Rose, Survey Corps Headquarters, Marley (later)

Appearance: Armin stands at 168 cm with a lean, delicate build. His soft blue eyes reflect intelligence and empathy, framed by short, blonde hair parted in the middle. His pale skin and youthful face carry a gentle expression, with a quiet, earnest voice. Subtle scars from battles mark his arms, hinting at his resilience despite his unassuming frame.

Outfit (Common): Armin wears the Survey Corps uniform: a brown jacket with Wings of Freedom, white pants, and a green cloak for expeditions. His ODM gear fits snugly, emphasizing his slight frame. Later, he dons a simple jacket and scarf in Marley, blending into civilian life while retaining a practical look.

Personality & Motivations: Armin is kind, introspective, and highly intelligent, often doubting his strength but unwavering in loyalty. His curiosity drives him to explore beyond the walls, motivated by dreams of peace and discovery. Guilt over sacrifices fuels his determination to prove his worth, balancing compassion with ruthless strategic decisions.

Skills & Capabilities: Armin wields the Colossal Titan, enabling massive destruction and steam emission. His tactical brilliance crafts battle strategies, excelling in analysis and deception. Proficient in ODM gear, he combines agility with precise blade work. His leadership grows, coordinating allies against global threats, though emotional weight tempers his confidence.

Equipment/Weapons/Gadgets: Armin uses standard ODM gear with gas canisters and grappling hooks. His dual swords are designed for Titan-slaying. As Colossal Titan, he relies on innate powers, carrying no additional gadgets beyond Survey Corps equipment.

Weaknesses & Fears: Physically weaker than peers, Armin tires quickly in direct combat. His self-doubt hampers decisiveness under pressure. The Colossal Titan‚Äôs slow transformation leaves him vulnerable. He fears failing his friends and losing hope for a peaceful world, haunted by the lives lost under his strategies.

Allies & Enemies: Allies: Eren Jaeger (childhood friend), Mikasa Ackerman (close ally), Jean Kirstein (comrade). Enemies: Reiner Braun (Armored Titan), Zeke Jaeger (Beast Titan), Marleyan Military.

Role in Attack on Titan: Armin‚Äôs intellect and Colossal Titan powers shape critical victories, guiding the Survey Corps through moral and strategic challenges. His pursuit of peace drives the narrative toward global reconciliation.

5.content:
Levi Ackerman, born in the Underground City beneath Wall Sina, endured a harsh childhood raised by his mother, Kuchel, until her death. Trained by his uncle, Kenny Ackerman, in combat and survival, Levi became a thug until Erwin Smith recruited him into the Survey Corps. Renowned as "Humanity's Strongest Soldier," his unparalleled skill in ODM gear and Titan-slaying defines his legend. Leading the Special Operations Squad, Levi‚Äôs loyalty to Erwin and his comrades drives his relentless fight against Titans, seeking a future beyond the walls.

Core Details:

Type: Soldier / Leader / Anti-Hero

Affiliations: Survey Corps, Special Operations Squad, Ackerman Clan, Erwin Smith

Setting: Attack on Titan, Paradis Island, Post-Fall of Wall Maria (845-854)

Gender/Age/Race: Male / Young Adult / Eldian (Ackerman)

Base of Operations: Wall Rose, Survey Corps Headquarters, Nomadic during expeditions

Appearance: Levi stands at 160 cm, with a compact, muscular build honed for combat. His sharp gray eyes exude intensity, framed by short, black hair with an undercut. Pale skin bears faint scars from battles, and his stern expression rarely softens. His low, calm voice carries authority, reflecting his disciplined demeanor and unyielding resolve.

Outfit (Common): Levi wears the Survey Corps uniform: a brown jacket with the Wings of Freedom, white pants, and a green cloak for expeditions. His ODM gear is meticulously maintained, accentuating his agile frame. A white cravat, a nod to his fastidious nature, complements his polished boots and dual swords.

Personality & Motivations: Levi is stoic, disciplined, and fiercely loyal, with a blunt demeanor and dry wit. His obsession with cleanliness masks a deep care for his comrades. Motivated by a promise to Erwin to eliminate Titans and secure freedom, he fights with unmatched dedication, haunted by past losses and driven to protect humanity.

Skills & Capabilities: Levi‚Äôs Ackerman lineage grants superhuman strength, speed, and reflexes. A master of ODM gear, he executes precise, acrobatic Titan-slaying maneuvers. His hand-to-hand combat and blade techniques are unmatched, often decapitating Titans single-handedly. Strategic instincts and leadership make him a battlefield cornerstone.

Equipment/Weapons/Gadgets: Levi wields ODM gear with gas canisters and grappling hooks for unmatched mobility. His dual swords, sharpened to perfection, slice through Titan napes with precision. Thunder Spears are used for heavy Titan targets, complementing his arsenal.

Weaknesses & Fears: Levi‚Äôs short stature limits raw power against larger foes, and overexertion risks injury despite his durability. Emotionally, he struggles with loss, particularly of his squad and Erwin. He fears failing those he‚Äôs sworn to protect, carrying the weight of their sacrifices silently.

Allies & Enemies: Allies: Erwin Smith (commander), Hange Zo√´ (comrade), Eren Jaeger (squad member). Enemies: Zeke Jaeger (Beast Titan), Reiner Braun (Armored Titan), Kenny Ackerman (former mentor).

Role in Attack on Titan: Levi is the Survey Corps‚Äô spearhead, embodying humanity‚Äôs defiance against Titans. His leadership and combat prowess shape key battles, inspiring hope while grappling with the cost of survival.

6.content:
Erwin Smith, born in Wall Sina, grew up questioning the monarchy‚Äôs secrecy about the outside world, sparked by his father‚Äôs forbidden theories. After his father‚Äôs death, Erwin joined the Survey Corps, rising to commander by 845. His strategic brilliance and unyielding pursuit of truth drive the Corps‚Äô expeditions beyond the walls. Recruiting Levi and forming the Special Operations Squad, Erwin leads with charisma, sacrificing countless lives to uncover the Titan mystery and secure humanity‚Äôs freedom, culminating in the push to retake Wall Maria.

Core Details:

Type: Commander / Strategist / Leader

Affiliations: Survey Corps, Special Operations Squad, 104th Training Corps, Eldian Military

Setting: Attack on Titan, Paradis Island, Post-Fall of Wall Maria (845-850)

Gender/Age/Race: Male / Young Adult / Eldian

Base of Operations: Wall Rose, Survey Corps Headquarters, Trost District

Appearance: Erwin stands at 188 cm with a commanding, muscular build. His sharp blue eyes convey resolve, framed by neatly combed blond hair. His chiseled face, marked by a strong jawline, exudes authority. A deep, resonant voice carries his charismatic speeches, reflecting his unshakeable determination.

Outfit (Common): Erwin dons the Survey Corps uniform: a brown jacket with the Wings of Freedom emblem, white pants, and a green cloak for expeditions. His ODM gear is paired with dual swords, and a bolo tie marks his rank, accentuating his tall, imposing frame.

Personality & Motivations: Erwin is charismatic, calculating, and resolute, prioritizing humanity‚Äôs survival over personal morality. His relentless pursuit of truth about the Titans and the world drives his leadership. Despite his stoic demeanor, he harbors guilt for the lives lost under his command, motivated to validate their sacrifices by achieving freedom for Eldians.

Skills & Capabilities: Erwin excels in strategic planning, devising formations like the Long-Range Scouting Formation. Proficient in ODM gear, he wields swords with precision in Titan combat. His leadership inspires loyalty, and his ability to manipulate political dynamics strengthens the Survey Corps‚Äô position against internal and external threats.

Equipment/Weapons/Gadgets: Erwin uses standard ODM gear with gas canisters and grappling hooks for mobility. His dual swords are designed for Titan-slaying, and he occasionally employs Thunder Spears for strategic strikes. A notebook for planning is a constant companion.

Weaknesses & Fears: Erwin‚Äôs single-minded focus on his goals risks alienating allies. Physically, he relies on strategy over brute strength, vulnerable in direct combat. He fears his sacrifices may be meaningless if the truth remains elusive, haunted by his father‚Äôs death and the weight of his soldiers‚Äô lives.

Allies & Enemies: Allies: Levi Ackerman (trusted captain), Hange Zo√´ (researcher), Dot Pixis (Garrison ally). Enemies: Rod Reiss (Royal Government), Zeke Jaeger (Beast Titan), Reiner Braun (Armored Titan).

Role in Attack on Titan: Erwin is the Survey Corps‚Äô visionary leader, driving humanity‚Äôs fight for freedom. His strategies shape pivotal battles, and his pursuit of truth redefines the world‚Äôs understanding of Titans, inspiring hope amidst sacrifice.

7.content:
Jean Kirstein, born in Trost District, joined the 104th Training Corps with dreams of a safe life in the Military Police. His pragmatic outlook clashed with Eren‚Äôs idealism, but the fall of Wall Maria and Marco‚Äôs death reshaped his perspective. Joining the Survey Corps, Jean‚Äôs tactical instincts and leadership grew, earning him a key role in the Special Operations Squad. His journey reflects a shift from self-preservation to selfless sacrifice, navigating moral dilemmas in the fight against Titans and Marley.

Core Details:

Type: Soldier / Leader / Strategist

Affiliations: Survey Corps, 104th Training Corps, Special Operations Squad, Anti-Marleyan Volunteers

Setting: Attack on Titan, Paradis Island, Post-Fall of Wall Maria (845-854)

Gender/Age/Race: Male / Young Adult / Eldian

Base of Operations: Trost District, Wall Rose, Survey Corps Headquarters

Appearance: Jean stands at 175 cm with a lean, athletic build from Corps training. His light brown, undercut hair frames sharp hazel eyes that carry a mix of cynicism and resolve. His fair skin shows minor combat scars, and his long face, often mocked as ‚Äúhorse-like,‚Äù holds a determined expression. His voice, smooth yet firm, conveys leadership with a hint of sarcasm.

Outfit (Common): Jean wears the Survey Corps uniform: a brown jacket with the Wings of Freedom emblem, white pants, and a green cloak for expeditions. His ODM gear fits snugly, highlighting his toned frame. Brown boots and a gray shirt complete the look, with a red armband occasionally marking his Eldian status.

Personality & Motivations: Jean is pragmatic, honest, and sharp-witted, often clashing with others due to his bluntness. Initially driven by self-interest, Marco‚Äôs death and camaraderie with the Corps fuel his commitment to protect humanity. He strives to lead effectively, balancing personal doubts with a desire to honor fallen friends.

Skills & Capabilities: Jean excels in ODM gear, using speed and precision to slay Titans. His tactical acumen shines in battle planning, often anticipating enemy moves. Proficient in hand-to-hand combat and Thunder Spear use, he adapts quickly, leveraging his leadership to coordinate squad maneuvers effectively.

Equipment/Weapons/Gadgets: Jean wields standard ODM gear with gas canisters and grappling hooks for mobility. His dual swords are paired with spare blades for Titan-slaying. Thunder Spears provide explosive power against armored targets, complementing his tactical arsenal.

Weaknesses & Fears: Jean‚Äôs hesitation in high-stakes decisions can delay action, and his bluntness strains alliances. Physically, he lacks the raw power of stronger comrades. He fears losing more friends and failing as a leader, haunted by Marco‚Äôs death and the weight of responsibility.

Allies & Enemies: Allies: Marco Bott (deceased friend), Armin Arlert (strategic partner), Mikasa Ackerman (comrade). Enemies: Reiner Braun (Armored Titan), Zeke Jaeger (Beast Titan), Marleyan Military.

Role in Attack on Titan: Jean embodies the reluctant hero, evolving from self-interest to leadership. His strategic mind and loyalty shape critical missions, balancing moral conflicts while driving the fight for humanity‚Äôs survival.

8.content:
Connie Springer hails from Ragako Village in Wall Rose, a small-town youth with dreams of making his family proud. Joining the 104th Training Corps at 12, he graduated eighth, showcasing agility and teamwork. After the fall of Wall Maria, Connie joined the Survey Corps, driven by a desire to protect humanity. The destruction of Ragako by Titans, later revealed as Zeke‚Äôs doing, hardened his resolve. Loyal and brave, Connie evolves from a naive soldier to a key player in the fight against Marley.

Core Details:

Type: Soldier / Scout / Ally

Affiliations: Survey Corps, 104th Training Corps, Special Operations Squad, Ragako Village

Setting: Attack on Titan, Paradis Island, Post-Fall of Wall Maria (845-854)

Gender/Age/Race: Male / Young Adult / Eldian

Base of Operations: Wall Rose, Survey Corps Headquarters, Nomadic during expeditions

Appearance: Connie stands at 158 cm, with a lean, wiry build optimized for speed. His bright gray eyes radiate optimism, framed by a shaved head of dark brown hair. Tanned skin reflects his rural roots, with a boyish face and wide grin. His high-pitched, energetic voice complements his quick movements, exuding youthful vigor.

Outfit (Common): Connie wears the Survey Corps uniform: a brown jacket with the Wings of Freedom emblem, white pants, and a green cloak for expeditions. His ODM gear fits snugly, highlighting his agile frame. Brown boots and a gray shirt complete the look, with spare blades strapped to his sides.

Personality & Motivations: Connie is cheerful, loyal, and impulsive, with a strong sense of camaraderie. Initially naive, his experiences foster resilience. Driven to avenge Ragako and protect his friends, he fights for a world free from Titan threats, balancing humor with growing maturity in dire circumstances.

Skills & Capabilities: Connie excels in ODM gear, using speed and agility for precise Titan-slaying. His hand-to-hand combat is solid, honed in training. Teamwork enhances his effectiveness in group tactics. While not a strategist, his quick reflexes and adaptability shine in chaotic battles.

Equipment/Weapons/Gadgets: Connie wields standard ODM gear with gas canisters and grappling hooks for mobility. His dual swords are standard-issue, designed for cutting Titan napes. Thunder Spears are used sparingly for heavy targets, complementing his agile combat style.

Weaknesses & Fears: Connie‚Äôs impulsiveness leads to rash decisions, and his smaller stature limits raw strength. Emotionally, he struggles with Ragako‚Äôs loss, fearing failure to protect his remaining friends. Overreliance on team support can leave him vulnerable in solo scenarios.

Allies & Enemies: Allies: Jean Kirstein (close friend), Sasha Blouse (best friend), Eren Jaeger (comrade). Enemies: Reiner Braun (Armored Titan), Zeke Jaeger (Beast Titan), Marleyan Military.

Role in Attack on Titan: Connie embodies the everyday soldier‚Äôs growth, contributing loyalty and agility to the Survey Corps. His journey reflects resilience and hope, supporting key missions against Titans and Marley.

9.content:
Floch Forster, a young Eldian from Wall Rose, joined the 104th Training Corps, surviving the Battle of Trost to become a Survey Corps member. Initially a minor soldier, his trauma during the Return to Shiganshina, witnessing mass casualties, radicalized him. Aligning with Eren Jaeger‚Äôs vision, Floch became a fervent Yeagerist leader, advocating for Eldian supremacy. His zeal led him to orchestrate uprisings, betray allies, and support the Rumbling, driven by a belief in Paradis‚Äô survival through extreme measures.

Core Details:

Type: Soldier / Antagonist / Leader

Affiliations: Yeagerists, Survey Corps (former), 104th Training Corps, Eren Jaeger

Setting: Attack on Titan, Paradis Island, Post-Return to Shiganshina (850-854)

Gender/Age/Race: Male / Young adult / Eldian

Base of Operations: Wall Rose, Shiganshina District, Yeagerist strongholds

Appearance: Floch stands at 175 cm with a wiry, lean build from military training. His light brown eyes burn with fanatical intensity, framed by short, reddish-blonde hair swept to one side. Pale skin shows faint battle scars, and his sharp features carry a smug expression. His voice, high and fervent, conveys unwavering conviction, often grating to opponents.

Outfit (Common): Floch wears the Survey Corps uniform early on: brown jacket with Wings of Freedom, white pants, and green cloak. As a Yeagerist, he dons a dark jacket, white shirt, and red armband, paired with black pants and boots. His ODM gear, used sparingly, highlights his lean frame, with a rifle slung across his back.

Personality & Motivations: Floch is zealous, cunning, and uncompromising, evolving from timid to fanatically devoted to Eren‚Äôs cause. His blunt demeanor alienates others, but his charisma rallies Yeagerists. Motivated by fear of Marleyan oppression and a desire for Eldian dominance, he seeks to reshape the world through the Rumbling, believing it‚Äôs Paradis‚Äô only path to survival.

Skills & Capabilities: Floch is proficient in ODM gear, executing agile Titan-slaying maneuvers. His marksmanship with rifles and Thunder Spears excels in anti-personnel combat. Strategic cunning enables effective leadership of Yeagerist rebellions, though his combat skills are average compared to elite soldiers like Levi.

Equipment/Weapons/Gadgets: Floch uses standard ODM gear with gas canisters and grappling hooks. He carries dual swords initially, later favoring rifles and Thunder Spears for ranged attacks. A Yeagerist armband symbolizes his allegiance, paired with basic military supplies.

Weaknesses & Fears: Floch‚Äôs average physical prowess limits him against elite fighters. His fanatical devotion clouds judgment, leading to reckless decisions. He fears Paradis‚Äô annihilation and betrayal by allies, haunted by past losses and the futility of peace without dominance.

Allies & Enemies: Allies: Eren Jaeger (leader), Samuel (Yeagerist), Daz (Yeagerist). Enemies: Levi Ackerman (Survey Corps), Armin Arlert (alliance member), Hange Zo√´ (former commander).

Role in Attack on Titan: Floch drives the Yeagerist uprising, embodying extremist ideology. His actions escalate conflict, challenging the Survey Corps and shaping the Rumbling‚Äôs course, representing the cost of radicalized loyalty in a fractured world.

10.content:
Keith Shadis, a former commander of the Survey Corps, led the regiment before Erwin Smith, driven by a vision to reclaim freedom from Titans. After repeated failures and losses, he stepped down, disillusioned, and became the head instructor of the 104th Training Corps in Wall Rose. His grueling training shaped recruits like Eren Jaeger, whom he knew through his past friendship with Grisha Jaeger. Keith‚Äôs unrequited love for Carla Jaeger and his perceived inadequacy haunt him, fueling his harsh yet dedicated mentorship.

Core Details:

Type: Instructor / Former Commander / Soldier

Affiliations: Survey Corps (former), 104th Training Corps, Grisha Jaeger

Setting: Attack on Titan, Paradis Island, Post-Fall of Wall Maria (845-850)

Gender/Age/Race: Male / Mid-40s / Eldian

Base of Operations: Wall Rose, Training Corps Barracks, Wall Maria (former)

Appearance: Keith stands at 198 cm, with a towering, muscular build weathered by years of combat. His stern brown eyes sit beneath heavy brows, framed by short, dark brown hair graying at the temples. A rugged beard covers his square jaw, and his tanned skin bears scars from past expeditions. His deep, gravelly voice carries authority, reflecting his disciplined yet burdened demeanor.

Outfit (Common): Keith wears the Training Corps uniform: a brown jacket with crossed swords insignia, white pants, and sturdy brown boots. As an instructor, he forgoes the Survey Corps‚Äô green cloak, opting for a practical black coat. His ODM gear, rarely used now, remains meticulously maintained, strapped to his broad frame.

Personality & Motivations: Keith is gruff, disciplined, and self-critical, hiding a deep sense of duty beneath his stern facade. Haunted by his perceived failures as commander, he‚Äôs driven to mold capable soldiers to protect humanity. His unrequited love for Carla and loyalty to her memory push him to guide Eren, seeking redemption through others‚Äô success.

Skills & Capabilities: Keith is a skilled ODM gear user, with expertise in Titan-slaying from his Survey Corps days. His hand-to-hand combat and tactical knowledge remain sharp. As an instructor, he excels in training, instilling discipline and survival skills in recruits, though he rarely engages in combat himself now.

Equipment/Weapons/Gadgets: Keith carries standard ODM gear with gas canisters and grappling hooks, paired with dual swords for training demonstrations. As an instructor, he uses minimal equipment, relying on whistles and training logs to manage recruits.

Weaknesses & Fears: Keith‚Äôs age and past injuries reduce his combat endurance. Emotionally, he‚Äôs crippled by self-doubt and guilt over failed expeditions and Carla‚Äôs death. He fears his efforts are futile, believing he‚Äôs not ‚Äúspecial‚Äù enough to change humanity‚Äôs fate.

Allies & Enemies: Allies: Eren Jaeger (former trainee), Grisha Jaeger (old friend), Erwin Smith (former comrade). Enemies: Titans (general), Marleyan Military (indirectly).

Role in Attack on Titan: Keith shapes the next generation of soldiers, indirectly influencing the fight against Titans through his trainees. His past leadership and personal sacrifices highlight the human cost of resistance in a Titan-dominated world.

lorebooks.name: Basics for Naruto Worl
lorebooks.website_description: If you have any feedback please write in Discussion section!
lorebooks.description: Political structure of world, Shinobi equipment, hidden village system, and main countries geo. Without reference to time period. No any jutsu.
lorebooks.creator: s_tayna

1.content: Feudal states where shinobi forces obey state authority. Political leadership held by ruler titled Daimyo. Continent's territory divided among Shinobi Godaikoku to ensure balance of power. Land of Earth in northwest. Land of Lightning in northeast. Land of Water in east. Land of Wind in southwest. Land of Fire occupies central part. Each country named according to predominant type of chakra nature in its territory. Each possesses its own kakurezato, representing military organization of highest power and training. Shinobi Godaikoku countries are most powerful nations. Their military might and political influence are approximately equal, ensuring stable balance. However, Land of Fire is considered most powerful and influential. During Fourth Shinobi World War, Shinobi Godaikoku countries united into single coalition with samurai representing Land of Iron. Combined forces fought against Eye of Moon Plan. Following war, Shinobi Godaikoku countries continue policy of strengthening alliances. Joint initiatives aimed at preserving peace and developing diplomatic ties have received official state-level approval.

2.content: Supreme ruler of feudal shinobi country, possessing full political authority. Daimyo decides foreign policy, state budget, resource allocation, and grants privileges to kakurezato. Daimyo holds authority to appoint new kage. Typically, candidate is determined by current kage. If kage dies, is incapacitated, or absent, daimyo decides new appointment. Procedure includes consultations with kakurezato council, jonin hancho, and official representatives. Daimyo attends final Chunin Shiken matches to bet on fights or identify promotion candidates. Permanent residence located in country's capital. Daimyo is constantly surrounded by numerous advisors and escorts, who often exhibit imperious, arrogant behavior towards civilians. Political disagreements between different daimyo frequently lead to armed conflicts. Resolution of consequences is delegated to seiki butai of respective kakurezato. Daimyo's lack of direct participation in military actions means awareness of destruction scale and human losses is absent, contributing to repetition of such situations. Crimes against daimyo's life are particularly grave offenses.

3.content: Territorial administrative unit within country inhabited by shinobi. Kakurezato supports its economy by training shinobi from young age and utilizing them for various missions. Rulers of shinobi godaikoku's kakurezato bear title of kage. Great Five' kakurezato are considered  most powerful. Before kakurezato's system was established, most shinobi clans were independent military formations that operated as mercenaries, frequently changing allies based on offered payment. This period is called Sengoku Jidai. With formation of organized kakurezato and centralized governance system, many clans integrated into structure.

4.content: Primary military and social class in feudal states. Main shinobi characteristic is ability to use various techniques via chakra control. Most shinobi reside in their country's kakurezato. Some belong to specialized clans. Shinobi carry out missions for rewards. In wartime, shinobi unite to defend their kakurezato and country territories. Shinobi are obligated to remain loyal to their kakurezato throughout their lives. Individuals who violate this loyalty and leave without permission are considered nukenin, sentenced to death.

5.content: Female shinobi. In Shinobi Academy, curriculum for girls additionally includes kunoichi classes, teaching basics of culture, behavior, and arts, including ikebana, as part of traditional training for missions requiring stealth and subtle social interaction.

6.content: Book listing ninjas on blacklist as targets for capture or elimination. Several tehaisho versions exist, each belonging to specific kakurezato. Entries made by kage or high-ranking officials. Book is given to jonins and ANBU members. List contains dangerous ninjas, nukenins, and security threats marked for elimination. Photos of destroyed nukenins are crossed out. ANBU units may have tasks to eliminate nukenins without leaving traces.

7.content: Shinobi who left own kakurezato with no intention of returning. Considered criminals who severed ties with home. Often become nukenin after committing crimes or for personal gain. Some continue to wear forehead protector but scratch out kakurezato's symbol. Kirigakure has special Oinin unit to eliminate nukenins. However, leaving does not always mean recognition as nukenin. After Fourth Great Ninja War, number of nukenin increased. Shinobi leave due to threats to their way of life or other reasons. Nukenin become more ruthless, often killing employers for large rewards.

8.content: Highest-ranking and typically strongest shinobi in Kakurezato. Chief representative responsible for administrative and military affairs. Each Kakurezato has one leader, but power is distributed among leader, advisors, and high-ranking shinobi. Method of electing Sato-osa varies among Kakuarezatos, including democratic elections or hereditary succession. Sato-osa from Great Five hold most power and respect, bearing title of Kage.

9.content: Leaders of Hidden Villages of Great Five, collectively called Gokage. Kage controls village activities: assigning missions and ensuring safety. Considered strongest ninja and supreme leader. Title introduced by Hashirama Senju after founding Konohagakure. System adopted by other countries. Kage rarely cooperate beyond formal events. Gokage Kaidan is sole meeting for pan-village matters. Election processes vary. In Konohagakure, Hokage appoints successor. If unable, Daimyo chooses with council consultation, requiring Jonin approval. Retired Kage keep title for life and may assist or return if successor dies. Jinchuriki tradition involves using Kage's relatives to demonstrate power and ensure loyalty.

10.content: Official missions performed by shinobi according to Kakurezato structure. Form basis of professional activity, classified into five rank categories by danger level: Rank D - simple, risk-free assignments; Rank C - minimal risk missions; Rank B - medium-difficulty; Rank A - high-risk; Rank S - extreme difficulty. Completion quality impacts shinobi's reputation and advancement. Failure consequences depend on mission nature and political course. Extreme or forbidden measures permitted, including sacrifices. Violence, deception, and information concealment allowed. If client distorts mission information, shinobi released from obligation. Mission costs influence client policy - some downplay danger to reduce cost, use mercenaries, or transfer missions to other Kakurezato. Yohei perform unsanctioned missions. In Konohagakure, shinobi receive first mission directly from Hokage.
